nodes.description: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was born near Samarra, north of Baghdad, in 1971.

nodes.description: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi had a reputation as a highly organised and ruthless battlefield tactician.

nodes.description: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was described as the world's most wanted man.

nodes.description: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was a cleric in a mosque in Samarra around 2003.
nodes.support_text: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was a cleric in a mosque in Samarra around 2003.

nodes.description: Theories about Baghdadi's early involvement in jihadism and his time at Camp Bucca.
nodes.support_text: Some believe he was already a jihadist during the rule of former Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Others suggest he was radicalised during the time he was held at Camp Bucca, a US facility in southern Iraq where many al-Qaeda commanders were detained.

nodes.description: Baghdadi emerged as the leader of an umbrella group in 2010 and was seen in public only when he declared the creation of a 'caliphate' in 2014. He reappeared in a video released by IS earlier this year.
nodes.support_text: Baghdadi emerged in 2010 as the leader of an umbrella group that included al-Qaeda in Iraq, and rose to prominence when IS militants captured the Iraqi city of Mosul in 2014, when he declared the creation of a 'caliphate'. That was the only time Baghdadi was seen in public. He reappeared in a video released by IS earlier this year.

nodes.description: The US officially designated him a 'terrorist' in October 2011.
nodes.support_text: In October 2011, the US officially designated him a 'terrorist' and offered a reward of $10m (£5.8m at the time) for information leading to his capture or death.

nodes.description: The US offered a reward of $10m for information leading to his capture or death, increased to $25m in 2017.
nodes.support_text: In October 2011, the US officially designated him a 'terrorist' and offered a reward of $10m (£5.8m at the time) for information leading to his capture or death. This was increased to $25m in 2017.

edges.support_text: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi announced the creation of a 'caliphate' in areas of Iraq and Syria in 2014. IS carried out a number of atrocities that resulted in thousands of deaths and imposed a brutal rule on almost eight million people in the areas under its control.

Baghdadi emerged in 2010 as the leader of an umbrella group that included al-Qaeda in Iraq, and rose to prominence when IS militants captured the Iraqi city of Mosul in 2014, when he declared the creation of a 'caliphate'. That was the only time Baghdadi was seen in public. He reappeared in a video released by IS earlier this year.

IS carried out a number of atrocities that resulted in thousands of deaths and imposed a brutal rule on almost eight million people in the areas under its control. The US declared the 'caliphate' defeated earlier this year.
The US declared the 'caliphate' defeated earlier this year. US special forces executed a 'daring night-time raid' and killed Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in northwest Syria on a late Saturday.

Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was born near Samarra, north of Baghdad, in 1971. Some believe he was already a jihadist during the rule of former Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Others suggest he was radicalised during the time he was held at Camp Bucca, a US facility in southern Iraq where many al-Qaeda commanders were detained.
The US officially designated him a 'terrorist' in October 2011 and offered a reward of $10m (£5.8m at the time) for information leading to his capture or death.
